questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of pain and redness on his back for 2 days. He returned yesterday from a vacation to East Africa with his parents, where he took multiple rides on hot air balloons. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, nonpruritic, erythematous rash with edema covering the extensor surface of both forearms, the shoulders, and the upper back, with small patches of skin exfoliation. The rash becomes pale when pressed and then rapidly regains color. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wound dressing is indicated for open burns (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) because they entail damage to the entire epidermal layer. In these cases, the ability of the skin to retain fluid is lost, making it prone to drying, which impairs wound healing and increases the risk of dehydration. This patient has no open burns, so dressing is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for burns that are partial-thickness or deeper (2nd-degree burns to 4th-degree burns), and generally only when the total body surface area involved is ≥ 20%, as these burns cause excessive fluid loss that cannot be sufficiently replaced orally. This patient has 1st-degree burns, in which the epidermis is intact and prevents fluid loss, and has no signs of hypovolemia (normotensive and normal heart rate). Therefore, intravenous fluid resuscitation is unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Lidocaine cream can potentially irritate damaged skin and should therefore generally be avoided in the management of sunburns.

D) INCORRECT:

Debridement is indicated when the dermis is exposed (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) to aid in wound healing. This patient has 1st-degree burns, which do not expose the dermis; debridement is unnecessary. In addition, because the dermis is intact, the burn will resolve on its own without scarring.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antimicrobial prophylaxis (e.g., mupirocin) is indicated for deep partial-thickness burns and full-thickness burns. This patient has a 1st-degree burn (with an intact epidermal barrier that protects against infection), which does not require antimicrobial prophylaxis.

F) CORRECT:

Topical moisturizers, such as those that contain aloe vera or calamine, are recommended to relieve symptoms of 1st-degree burns. These burns only involve the superficial epidermis and spare the dermis. The keratin barrier thus remains intact, retaining fluid and barring microbial entry. For this reason, no antimicrobial prophylaxis, fluid support, or debridement is necessary. Oral NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) may be given for pain and inflammation associated with sunburns. Important preventative measures to avoid sunburns include avoidance of direct sunlight (especially during midday), protective clothing, and application of broad-spectrum sunscreens (with sun protective factor ≥ 30) 15–30 minutes prior to sun exposure. Sunscreen should be reapplied every 2 hours and after water exposure.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with moderate sunburn

Patches of erythema are visible across the areas of skin that were most exposed to the sun. The absence of blisters distinguishes this presentation from a second-degree burn (partial-thickness burn).

Sunburn most commonly manifests as a first-degree burn, but higher-degree burns are possible with prolonged sun exposure.
questions.hint: A tender, erythematous, and edematous rash after sun exposure that blanches with pressure and refills rapidly is indicative of a superficial (1st-degree) sunburn. Approximately 15–20% of the surface area of this patient's body is involved.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a rash on his neck and back for the past 6 hours. He says that he first noticed some reddening of the skin on his back the previous evening, which turned into a blistering, red rash overnight. He went surfing the previous day and spent 5 hours at the beach. He reports having applied at least 1 oz of water-resistant SPF 30 sunscreen 30 minutes before leaving his home. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema of the skin over the upper back and dorsum of the neck, with 3 vesicles filled with clear fluid. The affected area is edematous and tender to touch. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms in the future?

choices.text: Apply sunscreen directly before getting into water
Only go outside on cloudy days
Apply at least 3 oz of sunscreen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

To provide adequate protection against sunburn, sunscreen with an adequate sun protection factor (SPF) should be applied at least 30 minutes prior to sun exposure and again after each exposure to water or after sweating. This patient's sunburn is likely due to the fact that he did not reapply sunscreen at any point during the 5 hours he was surfing. Even if this patient had not been swimming or surfing, sunscreen should be reapplied every 2–3 hours to prevent sunburn.

B) INCORRECT:

Sunscreen should be applied 30 minutes before sun exposure, which this patient did do. Additionally, sunscreen should often be applied several minutes before exposure to water to prevent the immediate washing off of the product.

C) INCORRECT:

Sun protection factor (SPF) 50 sunscreen provides only a negligible 1% increase in sun protection compared to the SPF 30 used by the patient, which already provides 97% protection. There are other factors concerning the application of sunscreen that contributed more to this patient's sunburn.

D) INCORRECT:

Cloud coverage does not provide adequate protection from ultraviolet (UV) radiation, and sunscreen should still be applied on cloudy days. Additional risk factors that increase risk of sunburn include UV reflection off of water and sand, which is likely to occur at the beach, as well as snow. UV radiation is also more intense at higher altitudes.

E) INCORRECT:

For most nonobese adults, 1 oz of sunscreen is sufficient to adequately cover skin and provide sufficient sun protection.

F) INCORRECT:

Sunscreen that is “water resistant” or “very water resistant” can provide sun protection for up to 40 or 80 minutes, respectively. The terms “waterproof” or “sweatproof” can no longer be used to market sunscreens, as sunscreen must always be reapplied after the specified period of time to prevent sunburn.
questions.hint: This patient has a painful, erythematous rash with blisters, which developed on sun-exposed areas after a day at the beach. This is typical of a sunburn.

questions.text: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trolamine salicylate absorbs UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

B) INCORRECT:

TMP/SMX is used to treat numerous infections (i.e., UTI, acne vulgaris, toxoplasmosis, impetigo, cellulitis). Although it is effective against skin infections, the sulfonamide component causes photosensitivity and increases the risk of skin damage from UVA and UVB radiation.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical vitamin E can reduce skin damage from UVB radiation. However, it does not provide protection from UVA radiation and therefore would still leave this patient at risk for premature aging of the skin.

D) INCORRECT:

Para-aminobenzoic acid is only able to filter out UVB radiation. This patient would not be protected from UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

E) CORRECT:

Mineral-based sunscreens (e.g., with zinc oxide, titanium oxide) are broad-spectrum sunscreens and provide full protection from UVA and UVB radiation by absorbing light in those spectrums, which prevents penetration into the dermis and premature aging of the skin. Sunscreens that have salicylates (e.g., trolamine salicylate), para-aminobenzoic acid, cinnamates (e.g., cinoxate), or octocrylene as the active ingredient can absorb UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.
questions.hint: Sunscreens that provide protection against both ultraviolet A (UVA) and ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation are recommended to prevent premature aging of the skin.

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of painful rash after spending several hours in the sun. Skin examination shows well-demarcated areas of erythema with some scaling on the face, chest, upper back, and arms. The affected areas are hot and sensitive to touch. The oral mucosa appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's skin findings?

choices.text: Vascular endothelial cell injury in the superficial dermis
Keratinocyte and fibroblast proliferation in the epidermis
Immune complex deposits at the dermoepidermal junction
Mast cell activation in the superficial dermis
Apoptosis of keratinocytes in the epidermis
T-cell-mediated inflammatory reaction in the dermis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema migrans, the dermatologic manifestation of stage I Lyme disease, is caused by injury to vascular endothelial cells in the superficial epidermis. Unlike this patient's rash, erythema migrans presents as a circular, slowly expanding, erythematous ring with a central clearing. The lesions are typically painless and accompanied by flu-like symptoms. Patients typically have a history of a recent hiking or camping trip, a tick bite, or travel to an endemic region of the US.

B) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of keratinocytes and fibroblasts in the epidermis is involved in the pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans. Lesions in acanthosis nigricans are velvety and hyperpigmented and typically occur in the axillae, groin, and neck. This dermatologic finding occurs most commonly in association with insulin resistance, although it can also represent a paraneoplastic syndrome. This patient's rash is well-circumscribed and erythematous, and she has no symptoms suggestive of insulin resistance or malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposition of immune complexes at the dermoepidermal junction is observed in the immunohistopathology of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The characteristic dermatologic finding of SLE is a malar rash which involves the nasal bridge and cheeks but spares the nasolabial folds. Patients with SLE can also develop oral ulcers. This patient has a well-demarcated rash in sun-exposed areas, and she does not have other symptoms of SLE including fevers, fatigue, myalgias, arthralgias, or lupus nephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Mast cell activation and initiation of the inflammatory cascade in the superficial epidermis is involved in the pathogenesis of a type I hypersensitivity reaction. These reactions occur within minutes of exposure to an allergen. The characteristic dermatologic finding in type I hypersensitivity reactions is urticaria, which consists of pruritic, erythematous plaques. This patient's rash is only present in sun-exposed regions, she has no history of recent allergen contact, and she has no other symptoms of a type I hypersensitivity reaction, such as angioedema, bronchospasm, abdominal cramping, rhinitis, and pulmonary edema.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's rash following prolonged sun exposure is consistent with dermatitis solaris, or sunburn. Sunburn is caused by ultraviolet (primarily UVB) radiation-induced damage of the epidermis, which results in keratinocyte apoptosis and release of inflammatory mediators within the epidermis and dermis. Lesions are painful and erythematous and appear within hours of sun exposure. Sunburn is typically restricted to sun-exposed skin, as reflected by involvement of this patient's face, chest, upper back, and arms, and sparing of the oral mucosa.

F) INCORRECT:

Contact between an antigen and pre-sensitized T lymphocytes in the dermis initiates the inflammatory cascade in type IV hypersensitivity reactions. The characteristic dermatologic finding in type IV hypersensitivity reactions is a pruritic, erythematous, papular rash that can progress to oozing vesicles. The rash develops within 12–48 hours of repeat exposure to an antigen like nickel, latex, or poison ivy, and spreads to other parts of the body by physical contact. This patient has no history of exposure to an allergen, and her rash is inconsistent with type IV hypersensitivity.
questions.hint: UVB-radiation causes DNA-damage of epidermal cells.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy will be traveling with his family to a sunny destination within the next few days. The mother asks for recommendations regarding sun protection because they will be in the sun for several hours per day with limited access to shade.
In addition to avoiding direct sunlight, what recommendation regarding sun protection is most appropriate for the child?

choices.text: Avoid travel to a sunny destination with a child of this age
Dress him in long, lightweight clothing and a hat, and apply sunscreen to limited exposed areas
Keep the child indoors or in deep shade except in the early morning and late evening hours
Apply sunscreen to the entire body every 3 to 4 hours
Dress him in lightweight protective clothing and a hat, but avoid the use of sunscreen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

As long as appropriate sun protective measures are taken when the child is outside, it is unnecessarily restrictive to discourage travel or to avoid all outside activities during daylight.

B) CORRECT:

Exposure to the sun’s damaging ultraviolet rays can lead to erythema and sunburn in the short term and eventually to skin cancers, including squamous-cell carcinoma, basal-cell carcinoma, and malignant melanoma. Sunscreen has been shown to protect against the development of precancers, such as actinic keratosis, as well as skin cancer. For children under age 6 months, both the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the American Academy of Dermatology suggest lightweight barrier clothing, wide-brim hats, and avoidance of direct sunlight (seek shade). However, when the sun cannot be avoided, sunscreen should be applied to small areas of the bodies of younger infants, such as the cheeks and backs of the hands.

Sunscreen, when applied liberally at 2 mL per square centimeter of skin, protects against erythema and subsequent sunburn of the skin. The sun protection factor (SPF) component of sunscreen is related to how long it takes for sunburn to occur. For example, if a person who normally develops sunburn in 20 minutes wears sunscreen with an SPF of 30, it will take 600 minutes (20 x 30) for that person to develop the same burn. Sunscreen is absorbed systemically, and some data from animal studies suggest that sunscreen may have endocrinologic effects. Infants have a higher body-surface area-to-volume ratio than adults and are thought to differ from adults in their absorption, metabolism, and excretion of sunscreen.

Although no toxicity has been reported from sunscreen use in infants or children, the broad application of sunscreen of any SPF is not recommended during early infancy. The AAP recommends regular and broad use of sunscreen in children beginning at 6 months of age. For younger infants, such as the child in this vignette, more-limited coverage is recommended. Inorganic sunscreens (e.g., those that are titanium oxide- or zinc oxide-based) tend to be less irritating, with less systemic absorption, and are therefore typically preferred in this age group.

As long as appropriate sun protective measures are taken when the child is outside, it is unnecessarily restrictive to discourage travel or to avoid all outside activities during daylight.

Key learning point: In addition to avoidance of direct sunlight and the use of sunscreen on exposed areas, a key sun protection recommendation for infants is to wear a hat and long, lightweight clothing.

C) INCORRECT:

As long as appropriate sun protective measures are taken when the child is outside, it is unnecessarily restrictive to discourage travel or to avoid all outside activities during daylight.

D) INCORRECT:

Although no toxicity has been reported from sunscreen use in infants or children, the broad application of sunscreen of any SPF is not recommended during early infancy. The AAP recommends regular and broad use of sunscreen in children beginning at 6 months of age. For younger infants, such as the child in this vignette, more-limited coverage is recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

For children under age 6 months, both the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the American Academy of Dermatology suggest lightweight barrier clothing, wide-brim hats, and avoidance of direct sunlight (seek shade). However, when the sun cannot be avoided, sunscreen should be applied to small areas of the bodies of younger infants, such as the cheeks and backs of the hands.

Apply at least 3 oz of sunscreen

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because of pain and redness on his back for 2 days. He returned yesterday from a vacation to East Africa with his parents, where he took multiple rides on hot air balloons. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a tender, nonpruritic, erythematous rash with edema covering the extensor surface of both forearms, the shoulders, and the upper back, with small patches of skin exfoliation. The rash blanches with pressure and rapidly regains color. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Debridement is indicated when the dermis is exposed (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) to aid in wound healing. This patient has 1st-degree burns, which do not expose the dermis; debridement is unnecessary. In addition, because the dermis is intact, the burn will resolve on its own without scarring.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antimicrobial prophylaxis (e.g., mupirocin) is indicated for deep partial-thickness burns and full-thickness burns. This patient has a 1st-degree burn (with an intact epidermal barrier that protects against infection), which does not require antimicrobial prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Wound dressing is indicated for open burns (i.e., partial-thickness or full-thickness burns) because they entail damage to the entire epidermal layer. In these cases, the ability of the skin to retain fluid is lost, making it prone to drying, which impairs wound healing and increases the risk of dehydration. This patient has no open burns, so dressing is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for burns that are partial-thickness or deeper (2nd-degree burns to 4th-degree burns), and generally only when the total body surface area involved is ≥ 20%, as these burns cause excessive fluid loss that cannot be sufficiently replaced orally. This patient has 1st-degree burns, in which the epidermis is intact and prevents fluid loss, and has no signs of hypovolemia (normotensive and normal heart rate). Therefore, intravenous fluid resuscitation is unnecessary.

E) CORRECT:

Topical moisturizers, such as those that contain aloe vera or calamine, are recommended to relieve symptoms of 1st-degree burns. These burns only involve the superficial epidermis and spare the dermis. The keratin barrier thus remains intact, retaining fluid and barring microbial entry. For this reason, no antimicrobial prophylaxis, fluid support, or debridement is necessary. Oral NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) may be given for pain and inflammation associated with sunburns. Important preventative measures to avoid sunburns include avoidance of direct sunlight (especially during midday), protective clothing, and application of broad-spectrum sunscreens (with sun protective factor ≥ 30) 15–30 minutes prior to sun exposure. Sunscreen should be reapplied every 2 hours and after water exposure.

Key learning point: First-degree (superficial) sunburns are managed with topical moisturizers like aloe vera for symptomatic relief, as the epidermal barrier remains intact and no debridement, antibiotics, or dressings are needed.
Image Description:

Upper body of a patient with moderate sunburn

Patches of erythema are visible across the areas of skin that were most exposed to the sun. The absence of blisters distinguishes this presentation from a second-degree burn (partial-thickness burn).

Sunburn most commonly manifests as a first-degree burn, but higher-degree burns are possible with prolonged sun exposure.
questions.hint: A tender, erythematous, and edematous rash after sun exposure that blanches with pressure and refills rapidly is indicative of a superficial (1st-degree) sunburn. Approximately 15–20% of the surface area of this patient's body is involved.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the ED after prolonged sun exposure. She reports severe burning pain over her back, shoulders, and arms, along with nausea and lightheadedness when standing. Physical examination shows erythema with multiple intact blisters and areas of weeping skin covering approximately 35% of her body surface area. Her mucous membranes appear dry. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Oral rehydration and supportive care with moisturizers
Immediate debridement of blisters and topical antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While antihistamines may help with pruritus, there is insufficient evidence on the effectiveness of topical corticosteroids for sunburn. Another step in management is required at this time.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has severe sunburn and accompanying dehydration (dry mucous membranes and orthostatic symptoms). Oral rehydration is the priority in severe sunburn to compensate for excessive fluid loss and treat dehydration, which can impair tissue perfusion and healing. Supportive care with moisturizers helps maintain skin barrier function and promotes healing. Blisters may also require dressings and topical antiseptic ointment.

C) INCORRECT:

Intact blisters should be left unbroken, as this provides a protective barrier that reduces the risk of infection. Debridement of blisters increases the risk of secondary infection and impairs natural healing processes.

D) INCORRECT:

Ice packs should be avoided because they cause vasoconstriction of dermal blood vessels, which can result in additional tissue damage. Topical anesthetics are not the primary treatment for severe sunburn with systemic effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are not indicated for uncomplicated sunburn, even with blistering. Silver sulfadiazine is typically reserved for deeper burns and is not appropriate for sunburn management.
